sections.title: A Key Wo\b\t Ana\fysis of Eng\fish Intensifying A\tve\bbs in Ma\fe an\t Fema\fe Speech in ICE-GB ∗∗∗∗
paragraphs: Jieun Jeon \bn\t J\be-Woon\f Choe
Dep\brtment of Lin\fuistics, Kore\b University,
An\bm-\ton\f Seon\fbuk-\fu, Seoul \bn\t 136-701, Kore\b

{jejeon, jchoe}@kore\b.\bc.kr Abst\bact. L\bkoff (1975), \b pioneerin\f stu\ty of women’s l\bn\fu\b\fe, su\f\feste\t \b ten\tency for women to use more of he\t\fes \bn\t intensifiers. Subsequent stu\ties still \bttr\bct some opposin\f (F\bhy, 2002; Nem\bti \bn\t B\byer, 2007) or reinforcin\f (Br\b\t\bc et al., 1995; N\bv\bl\binen, 2008) views. This p\bper shows how \b key wor\t \bn\blysis offers \bn empiric\bl evi\tence on the use of intensifyin\f \b\tverbs in m\ble \bn\t fem\ble speech b\bse\t on ICE-GB. We use the Key\b\trd\f f\bcility in Wor\tSmith tools (Scott, 1999) which h\bs been use\t in sever\bl stu\ties \bs me\bns for \tescribin\f the ch\br\bcteristics of \tifferent \fenres (S\br\tinh\b, 2000; Culpeper, 2002, 2009; Xi\bo \bn\t McEnery, 2005). One of the issues with respect to usin\f Key\b\trd\f f\bcility is the selection of the most \bppropri\bte reference corpus. Therefore, \bnother \fo\bl of this p\bper is to test sever\bl possibilities for the selection of the \bppropri\bte reference corpus for key wor\t \bn\blysis in terms of its size \bn\t composition. Keywo\b\ts: Intensifyin\f A\tverbs, ICE-GB, Wor\tSmith, Key wor\t, Reference corpus \C \C \C ∗ We \bre \fr\bteful to Dr. Seun\fw\bn H\b \bn\t \bnonymous reviewers for their helpful comments. All the rem\binin\f
errors, of course, \bre solely our responsibility. This work w\bs supporte\t by Br\bin Kore\b 21 Project.  Copyri\fht 2009 by Jieun Jeon \bn\t J\be-Woon\f Choe

sections.title: 1 Int\bo\tuction
paragraphs: One of the ch\br\bcteristic fe\btures of women’s speech, \bccor\tin\f to L\bkoff (1975:53-54), is th\bt women use, \bmon\f others, he\t\fes such \bs well, y’kn\tw, kinda \bn\t intensive \f\t more frequently th\bn men. Quirk \bn\t Greenb\bum (1973) c\blls them “\b\tverbi\bl qu\blific\btion” \bs bein\f points on \bn intensity sc\ble which m\by be hi\fh or low. For ex\bmple, in (1\b), very, \f\t, quite hei\fhten or \bmplify the sem\bntic me\bnin\f of the \bssertion, while in (1b), a bit, \f\trt \tf, kind \tf \tecre\bse the force of \bssertion.

(1) \b. He is (very/so/quite) re\bson\bble. b. He is (\b bit/sort of/kin\t of) re\bson\bble.  Intensifiers in (1\b) express the spe\bker’s stron\f commitment, \bn\t those in (1b) express the spe\bker’s reluct\bnce to commit to the v\bli\tity of th\bt \bssertion. In this p\bper, we will refer to them \bs “intensifyin\f \b\tverbs.”

L\bkoff (1975:66) cl\bims th\bt the tent\btiveness \bn\t powerless of women’s l\bn\fu\b\fe reflecte\t in he\bvy use of intensifyin\f \b\tverbs. Her pioneerin\f work provi\te\t one of the most influenti\bl moment\b in the feminist movement (Co\btes \bn\t C\bmeron, 1988). However, it \blso st\brte\t \b hot controversy re\f\br\tin\f the v\bli\tity of her lin\fuistic observ\btions \bn\t cl\bims. Dubois \bn\t Crouch (1975:289), for ex\bmple, criticize\t th\bt her investi\f\btive metho\t is introspective, \bsystem\btic, uncontrolle\t, \bn\t unverifi\bble observ\btion. The controversy is still \blive \bs L\bkoff \bn\t Bucholtz (2004) shows, \bn\t we c\bn still fin\t some subsequent stu\ties th\bt supports 210 23rd Pacific Asia Conference on Language, Information and Computation, pages 210–219   (Br\b\t\bc et al., 1995; N\bv\bl\binen, 2008) or \tis\bpproves (F\bhy, 2002; Nem\bti \bn\t B\byer, 2007) L\bkoff’s lin\fuistic \fener\bliz\btions, if not her feministic interpret\btion of them.

The purpose of this p\bper is to show how \b key wor\t \bn\blysis offers \bn empiric\bl verific\btion of the use of intensifyin\f \b\tverbs between m\ble \bn\t fem\ble speech b\bse\t on the Intern\btion\bl Corpus of En\flish-Gre\bt Brit\bin (ICE-GB), \b st\bn\t\br\t l\br\fe-sc\ble corpus for present-\t\by British En\flish. Our m\bin rese\brch question is: Are L\bkoff’s cl\bims \bn\t \fener\bliz\btions supporte\t by \t\bt\b extr\bcte\t from ICE-GB? Rel\bte\t question is how this c\bn be prove\t by some st\btistic\bl tests. Specific\blly, the questions th\bt involve st\btistic\bl issues to be \b\t\tresse\t in this p\bper \bre: 1) Wh\bt \bre the intensifyin\f \b\tverbs ch\br\bcteristic\blly use\t by fem\ble \bn\t m\ble spe\bkers respectively? 2) Wh\bt \bre the metho\tolo\fic\bl issues involve\t?

We use the Key\b\trd\f f\bcility in Wor\tSmith tools (Scott, 1999) which h\bs been use\t in sever\bl stu\ties \bs me\bns for \tescribin\f the ch\br\bcteristics of \tifferent \fenres (S\br\tinh\b, 2000; Culpeper, 2002, 2009; Xi\bo \bn\t McEnery, 2005). “Key wor\t” is \b term for st\btistic\blly si\fnific\bnt lexic\bl item which is most or le\bst frequent in \b \fiven context (corpus) comp\bre\t with other context (corpus) \bs \b reference. In this p\bper, we \bpply such \b well est\bblishe\t metho\t of extr\bctin\f key wor\ts to the question \bt h\bn\t, n\bmely, which intensifyin\f \b\tverbs \bre ch\br\bcteristic\blly use\t in fem\ble corpus comp\bre\t with m\ble corpus, or vice vers\b.

One of the issues with respect to usin\f the Key\b\trd\f function is the selection of most \bppropri\bte reference corpus. Two questions th\bt \bre r\bise\t concern the size \bn\t the composition of the reference corpus. It is obvious the selection of the \bppropri\bte reference corpus h\bs much relev\bnce to the results for key wor\t se\brch. Therefore, \bnother \fo\bl of this p\bper is to test sever\bl possibilities for the selection of the \bppropri\bte reference corpus for key wor\t \bn\blysis in terms of its size \bn\t composition.

sections.title: 2 P\bevious stu\ties: Issues on Key wo\b\t
paragraphs: In corpus lin\fuistics, the concept of \b key wor\t, \bn\t its usefulness for lin\fuistic \fener\bliz\btions, is r\bther well est\bblishe\t. E\brlier stu\ties refer to key wor\ts \bs wor\ts th\bt embo\ty concepts th\bt \bre soci\blly or cultur\blly import\bnt (e.\f., Firth, 1957; Willi\bms, 1983). Accor\tin\f to Culpeper (2002, 2009), the term key wor\ts c\bn be seem \bs \bnother term for style m\brkers which \bre wor\ts whose frequencies \tiffer si\fnific\bntly from their frequencies in \b norm.

Previous stu\ties \b\topte\t v\brious metho\ts for key wor\t extr\bction. For ex\bmple, R\byson et al. (1997) ex\bmine wor\ts most ch\br\bcteristic of m\ble \bn\t fem\ble subcorpus by \b comp\brison of the wor\ts m\brke\t by \b very hi\fh chi-squ\bre

v\blue of \tifference. O\bkes \bn\t F\brrow (2007) \blso use the chi-squ\bre test to fin\t the voc\bbul\bry most typic\bl of seven \tifferent ICAME corpor\b, e\bch representin\f the En\flish use\t in \b p\brticul\br country. A more convenient \bn\t e\bsy w\by to extr\bct key wor\ts is to use some re\b\tily \bv\bil\bble tools, for ex\bmple, the Key\b\trd\f f\bcility in Wor\tSmith tools (Scott, 1999), th\bt \fives v\brious options in the menu. This pro\fr\bm con\tucts \b st\btistic\bl comp\brison between the wor\ts of \b corpus (or wor\tlist) \bn\t \b reference corpus, in or\ter to i\tentify wor\ts th\bt \bre unusu\blly frequent, in other wor\ts, key wor\ts (Culpeper 2009:33).

In Key\b\trd\f f\bcility, key wor\ts \bre \terive\t by keyness v\blue which is c\blcul\bte\t either by the Te\t Dunnin\f's Lo\f Likelihoo\t test or by the Chi-squ\bre test. In or\ter to \bpply to Key \b\trd\f f\bcility, we nee\t 1) the frequency list of t\br\fet corpus, 2) the frequency list of reference corpus, \bn\t 3) the selection of st\btistic\bl v\blue.

Culpeper (2002, 2009) \bn\blyses the ch\br\bcters speech in Sh\bkespe\bre’s R\tme\t and Juliet usin\f the Key\b\trd\f f\bcilities. He h\bs \fener\bte\t \b list of key wor\ts for the m\bin ch\br\bcters \bn\t ex\bmine\t the function \bn\t context of the key wor\ts in or\ter to v\bli\t\bte \bn\t \bccount for the results. The not\bble thin\f in his stu\ty is the selection of reference corpus. In his R\tme\t and Juliet \bn\blysis, the comp\br\btive reference corpus w\bs the speech of the six ch\br\bcters minus the one bein\f investi\f\bte\t (e.\f. Romeo’s speech w\bs comp\bre\t with the speech of the other five 211   ch\br\bcters). There \bre issues on the choice of corpor\b for comp\brison in \bt le\bst two w\bys: size \bn\t composition. The issues rel\bte\t to reference corpus will be \tiscusse\t in section 4.

sections.title: 3 Data, Metho\to\fogy, an\t Resu\fts
paragraphs: Our \bn\blysis of the \t\bt\b procee\te\t \bs follows:

(1) We collecte\t \t\bt\b from the Intern\btion\bl Corpus of En\flish (ICE-GB) which cont\bins \b million wor\ts of 200 written \bn\t 300 spoken En\flish texts (Nelson, W\bllis \bn\t A\brts, 2002). Usin\f ICECUP 3.1 (ICE Corpus Utility Pro\fr\bm), we built subcorpor\b \bccor\tin\f to the sociolin\fuistic v\bri\bble of our choice in this stu\ty, n\bmely, spe\bker \fen\ter. ICE-GB is fully t\b\f\fe\t \bn\t p\brse\t so we c\bn extr\bct in \b r\bther precise m\bnner the sentences cont\binin\f intensifiers in \b \fiven subcorpus.
Tab\fe 1: Distribution of subcorpus between Fem\ble \bn\t M\ble speech1

Fem\ble M\ble Number of Spe\bkers 532 1,116 Number of Sentences 27,045/28,812 49,702/53,426 Number of Wor\ts 287,434/284,262 584,497/682,590  In the whole of ICE-GB corpus for which \fen\ter of spe\bker is in\tic\bte\t, we fin\t th\bt m\ble spe\bkers (1,116) h\bve \b l\br\fer sh\bre of the p\brticip\bnts th\bn fem\ble spe\bkers (532) \bs pro\tucers of the \t\bt\b in the corpus. M\ble corpus, consistin\f of 584,497 wor\ts, is two times \bs l\br\fe \bs fem\ble corpus th\bt cont\bins 287,434.

(2) The extr\bcte\t \t\bt\b were then fe\t into Wor\tSmith \bfter some preprocessin\f. For ex\bmple, the p\brse\t texts (.tre files), the output of the se\brch function from ICE-GB, \bre shown in the left-h\bn\t si\te in Fi\fure 1.   Figu\be 1: Preprocessin\f the p\brse\t text extr\bcte\t from ICE-GB

\C \C \C 1 ICE-GB \toes not provi\te \b w\by to extr\bct whole subcorpor\b \bccor\tin\f to \b soci\bl v\bri\bble only, so we trie\t to extr\bct the m\bxim\bl size \bllowe\t. The numbers \bfter the sl\bsh in e\bch cell in T\bble 1 in\tic\bte the number of wor\ts or sentences reporte\t by ICE-GB \bs the tot\bl size of the corpus belon\fin\f to the soci\bl v\bri\bble selecte\t, \bn\t the prece\tin\f numbers in\tic\bte the size we were \bble to extr\bct. 212   They were converte\t to the forms \fiven in the ri\fht-h\bn\t si\te in the fi\fure. In or\ter to simplify the process, we \bctu\blly converte\t \bll the wor\ts other th\bn the intensifyin\f \b\tverbs into their c\bte\fories, \bs shown in the bottom ri\fht-h\bn\t si\te.

(3) In Wor\tSmith, there is \b function c\blle\t Wor\tlist th\bt \terives \b wor\t list from the input corpus. Sep\br\bte lists were \fener\bte\t for the t\br\fet corpus \bn\t the reference corpus respectively. In the fem\ble subcorpus, the type of intensifyin\f \b\tverbs counts \bs 180 \bn\t token of them 4,614. In the m\ble subcorpus, the type of intensifyin\f \b\tverbs numbers 251 \bn\t token of them 8,226. The top 10 r\bnk-or\tere\t wor\t frequency in e\bch subcorpus is shown in T\bble 2.  Tab\fe 2: The top 10 r\bnk-or\tere\t wor\t frequency for intensifyin\f \b\tverbs
Fem\ble (top ten) M\ble (top ten) VERY 761 VERY 1,579 SORTOF 335 MORE 735 QUITE 321 QUITE 587

SO 314 SO 374 MORE 267 MUCH 355 REALLY 207 SORTOF 346 MUCH 200 MOST 344 ABOUT 175 ABOUT 337 TOO 164 TOO 301 MOST 119 AS 290  As T\bble 2 shows, the most frequent wor\t is ‘very’ in the both of fem\ble \bn\t m\ble corpor\b.2

In f\bct, only one item ‘a\f’ from m\ble b\bse\t list \toes not \bppe\br \bmon\fst the top 10 in the fem\ble b\bse\t list, \bn\t ‘really’ in fem\ble list. So the top ten lists \to not seem to \tifferenti\bte much between m\ble \bn\t fem\ble speech. It \toes not me\bn th\bt the most frequent wor\t is the most typic\bl wor\t in e\bch corpus, \bs it \toes not m\bke much sense th\bt \blmost the s\bme set of wor\ts \bre typic\bl both of m\ble \bn\t fem\ble speech. The number of common intensifyin\f \b\tverbs is 140. The number of wor\t types shown only in fem\ble subcorpus is 40, while th\bt in m\ble corpus is 111.

(4) The next step is to m\bke \b list of key wor\ts for files of e\bch \fen\ter usin\f the Key\b\trd\f function of Wor\tSmith. In choosin\f the reference corpus for comp\brison, the fem\ble \bn\t m\ble subcorpor\b were \tirectly comp\bre\t with e\bch other (Culpeper, 2002). So for the fem\ble subcorpus, we chose the m\ble subcorpus \bs its reference corpus, \bn\t vice vers\b. In this stu\ty, chi-squ\bre w\bs chosen \bs the st\btistic\bl metric, \bn\t the si\fnific\bnce level (p-v\blue) w\bs set \bt 0.01 followin\f Culpeper (2009).3

The result of the oper\btion is shown in the followin\f two t\bbles. T\bble 3 presents the list of 11 key wor\ts in fem\ble texts.     \C \C \C 2 In the c\bse of some multi-wor\t \b\tverbi\bl expressions like \f\trt \tf, a bit, etc, we \telete\t the sp\bce lest e\bch wor\t is
counte\t sep\br\btely. 3 Culpeper (2009) selecte\t the lo\f-likelihoo\t test for si\fnific\bnce, but he reporte\t th\bt the s\bme results were
reve\ble\t with only minor \bn\t occ\bsion\bl \tifferences in the r\bnkin\f of key wor\ts when he repe\bte\t the \bn\blysis
with the chi-squ\bre test. In our stu\ty, we \blso ev\blu\bte\t the results from both the lo\f-likelihoo\t test \bn\t the chi-
squ\bre test. We foun\t th\bt the lo\f-likelihoo\t test \bllows us to \fet \b little more number of key wor\ts th\bn the chi-
squ\bre test, but \b\t\tition\bl key wor\ts which were \terive\t in lo\f-likelihoo\t test \bre not si\fnific\bnt in terms of
\tispersion. So we chose to use the chi-squ\bre test. The \tiscussion \bbout \tispersion will be \te\blt in section 5. 213
Tab\fe 3: Key wor\t list from fem\ble subcorpus <X2 , P=0.01>

Key wor\t Freq. % RC. Freq. RC. % Keyness REALLY 207 0.07 108 0.02 151.46 SORTOF 335 0.12 346 0.06 80.48 SO 315 0.11 324 0.06 76.43 ABIT 109 0.04 132 0.02 15.85 THAT 42 0.01 35 15.27 ALL 74 0.03 81 0.01 14.66 TERRIBLY 19 10 12.47 COMPLETELY 46 0.02 49 9.58 TOO 164 0.06 249 0.04 8.20 SLIGHTLY 54 0.02 64 0.01 8.18 ATALL 95 0.03 134 0.02 7.14  “RC” in T\bble 3 st\bn\ts for “Reference Corpus” \bn\t “%” in\tic\btes the percentile of the frequency v\blue rel\btive to the whole subcorpus. The \te\free of keyness of e\bch intensifyin\f \b\tverbs is shown in the ri\fhtmost “Keyness” column in the t\bble, \bn\t the intensifyin\f \b\tverbs \bre sorte\t in the \tescen\tin\f or\ter of the keyness v\blue. The intensifyin\f \b\tverbs ch\br\bcteristic\blly use\t by the fem\ble spe\bkers, shown in the \bbove t\bble, mostly seem to h\bve somethin\f to \to with some emotion\bl st\bte of the spe\bker.

Rec\bll th\bt L\bkoff (1975) h\bs liste\t \bn intensifyin\f \b\tverb \f\t \bs \b kin\t of expression th\bt in\tic\btes ch\br\bcteristic fem\bleness. She \br\fues even the intensifyin\f \b\tverb \f\t c\bn be consi\tere\t \bs \b he\t\fe.  “Here we h\bve \bn \bttempt to he\t\fe on one’s stron\f feelin\fs, \bs thou\fh to s\by: I feel stron\fly \bbout this—but I \t\bre not m\bke it cle\br h\tw stron\f. To s\by ‘I like him very much,’ woul\t be to s\by precisely th\bt you like him to \b \fre\bt extent. To s\by, ‘I like him so much’ we\bsels on th\bt intensity: \b\f\bin, \b \tevice you’\t use if you felt it unseemly to show you h\b\t stron\f emotions, or to m\bke stron\f \bssertions, but felt you h\b\t to s\by somethin\f \blon\f those lines \bnyw\by.” (L\bkoff 1975: 54-5)

T\bble 3 inclu\tes not only \f\t, but other simil\br expressions like really, that, all, terribly, c\tmpletely, t\t\t, \bn\t at all th\bt “express the spe\bker’s stron\f commitment.” L\bkoff (1975) \blso liste\t some he\t\fes ‘well, y’kn\tw, kinda’ \bs fem\ble speech. T\bble 3 \toes not inclu\te \bny of the three, but \f\trt \tf, a bit \bn\t \flightly c\bn be s\bi\t to “express the spe\bker’s reluct\bnce to commit to the v\bli\tity of th\bt \bssertion” \bn\t c\bn be re\f\br\te\t \bs he\t\fes. Then \toes our result confirm L\bkoff’s cl\bim? Before \bnswerin\f it, we nee\t to check wh\bt the intensifiers \bre th\bt show ch\br\bcteristic m\bleness. The followin\f t\bble is the list of expressions from the m\ble subcorpus me\bsure\t \b\f\binst the fem\ble subcorpus.

Tab\fe 4: Key wor\t list from m\ble subcorpus <X2 , P=0.01> Key wor\t Freq. % RC. Freq. RC. % Keyness RIGHT 137 0.02 32 0.01 14.43 ENTIRELY 60 0.01 7 14.37 WELL 138 0.02 38 0.01 9.80 SOME 48 9 6.85  T\bble 4 lists “stron\f commitment” \b\tverb, right \bn\t entirely, \bn\t he\t\fes, well \bn\t \f\tme.4

Notice th\bt well cite\t in L\bkoff (1975) w\bs \bs \b typic\bl fem\ble expression, so our result \C \C \C 4 It is not so obvious to us whether entirely in T\bble 4 \bn\t \bt \bll in T\bble 3 c\bn be tre\bte\t \bs he\t\fes \bccor\tin\f to L\bkoff’s interpret\btion since they seem to in\tic\bte some extreme en\t on \b sc\ble in \b very cle\br w\by. 214   contr\b\ticts her cl\bim in th\bt re\f\br\t. However the spirit of her cl\bim still seems to be preserve\t when T\bble 3 \bn\t T\bble 4 \bre comp\bre\t with e\bch other. There \bre two thin\fs to note between the two t\bbles. One is the number of items in the list, n\bmely 11 in T\bble 3 \bn\t four in T\bble 4. The other is the Keyness v\blues for e\bch item in the list. The four expressions in T\bble 4 correspon\t to those in the lower h\blf in T\bble 3 in terms of their keyness v\blues, which me\bns they \bre r\bther we\bk in showin\f ch\br\bcteristic m\bleness comp\bre\t to those in T\bble 3. So we c\bn tent\btively conclu\te th\bt our \bn\blysis shows fem\ble spe\bkers ch\br\bcteristic\blly use \b lot more intensifiers, which, \bccor\tin\f to L\bkoff, reflects some typic\bl, less confi\tent, \bttitu\te of the fem\ble spe\bkers in terms of power rel\btions.

Our tent\btive conclusion, however, requires further investi\f\btion in \bt le\bst two respects. One question concerns the choice of the reference corpus, \bn\t the other is the question of \tispersion, th\bt is, how represent\btive or spre\b\t-out in their use \bre the items chosen in the corpus. We will \tiscuss these two subjects in turn in the followin\f two sections.

sections.title: 4 Se\fection of the app\bop\biate \befe\bence co\bpus
paragraphs: In \bny key wor\t \bn\blysis, the choice of \t\bt\b for comp\brison (the reference corpus) is \bn issue. Scott \bn\t Tribble (2006:58) su\f\fest th\bt it “shoul\t be \bn \bppropri\bte s\bmple of the l\bn\fu\b\fe which the text we \bre stu\tyin\f (the “no\te-text”) is written in.” Two m\bin issues rel\bte\t to the selection of the reference corpus \bre size \bn\t composition, \bs summ\brize\t below:  (2) \b. the size of the reference corpus
>> l\br\fer, simil\br, sm\bller th\bn t\br\fet corpus
b. the composition of the reference corpus

>> inclusion or exclusion of t\br\fet corpus  Concernin\f the issue (2\b), one of the most pressin\f questions with respect to usin\f key wor\ts seems to be wh\bt woul\t be the i\te\bl size of \b reference corpus. Tribble (1999:171) cl\bims th\bt the size of the corpus from which the reference wor\tlist is cre\bte\t is rel\btively unimport\bnt. Xi\bo \bn\t McEnery (2005:70) comp\bre\t two reference corpor\b, the 100-million-wor\t British N\btion\bl Corpus \bn\t the one million-wor\t Freibur\f-LOB Corpus, \bn\t \bchieve\t \blmost i\tentic\bl key wor\t lists, thus conclu\tin\f th\bt the size of the reference corpus is not very import\bnt in m\bkin\f \b key wor\t list. However, Wen\ty \bn\t Corbett (2009) point out th\bt “key wor\ts \bre more sensitive to the size of \b corpus, for ex\bmple, lon\fer texts will cont\bin fewer unique occurrences of p\brticul\br wor\ts”. Scott \bn\t Tribble (2006:64) conclu\te th\bt “while the choice of reference corpus is import\bnt, \bbove \b cert\bin size, the proce\ture throws up \b robust core of key wor\ts whichever reference corpus use\t.”

Simil\brly, but more specific\blly, S\br\tinh\b (2000) propose\t th\bt \b reference corpus th\bt is five times \bs l\br\fe \bs the stu\ty corpus yiel\te\t \b l\br\fer number of key wor\ts th\bn \b sm\bller reference corpus. So it seems there \bre some unresolve\t questions re\f\br\tin\f the size of the reference corpus. Specific\blly, we woul\t like to \b\t\tress two questions in our current rese\brch: 1) If the reference corpus shoul\t be l\br\fer th\bn t\br\fet corpus, then how much l\br\fer shoul\t it be. 2) If the reference corpus of \b sm\bller size th\bn the t\br\fet corpus shoul\t be strictly \tis\bllowe\t. The secon\t question is especi\blly import\bnt to us bec\buse the result reporte\t in T\bble 4 w\bs on the b\bsis of \b sm\bller size\t reference corpus. One mi\fht le\fitim\btely question if the sm\bll number of items in T\bble 4, comp\bre\t to those in T\bble 3, \bre \b result of the reference corpus of \b sm\bller size.

Then, wh\bt is the \bppropri\bte size of the reference corpus which is \foo\t for comp\brison? The followin\f two t\bbles show how the resultin\f lists of key wor\ts v\bry \tepen\tin\f on the rel\btive size of the reference corpus in our stu\ty. When there w\bs \b nee\t to r\bn\tomly “\townsize” the subcorpus so th\bt we c\bn m\bke it fit to our t\br\fet r\btio, we use\t \b R\bn\tom S\bmple function in ICECUP to th\bt effect. 215    Tab\fe 5: Fem\ble key wor\ts in the \tifferent “size” of reference corpus T\br\fet Reference R\btio Fem\ble key wor\ts

\b. m\ble20 (133,505) 0.46 re\blly, sort of, so, quite, \b bit, sli\fhtly, much (7) b. m\ble45 (308,445) 1.07 re\blly, sort of, so, \b bit, th\bt, very, too, sli\fhtly, \bll, quite, completely, \bt \bll, much (13) c. m\ble60 (408,802) 1.42 re\blly, sort of, so, \b bit, \bt \bll, quite, \bll, th\bt, much, terribly, very, sli\fhtly (12) \t. m\ble80 (546,214) 1.90 re\blly, sort of, so, \b bit, th\bt, terribly, quite, \bt \bll, \bll, sli\fhtly, very, completely, much (13) fem\ble100 (287,434)      2.03 re\blly, sort of, so, \b bit, th\bt, \bll, terribly, completely, too, sli\fhtly, \bt \bll (11) f. fem\ble80 (231.402) 2.52 re\blly, sort of, so, terribly, \b bit, completely, th\bt, \bll (8) \f. fem\ble60 (173,767) 3.36
re\blly, so, sort of, th\bt, \bll, terribly, \bwfully
h. fem\ble40 (115.091) 5.07 re\blly, sort of, so, in the le\bst (4)

i. fem\ble20 (58,788) e. m\ble100 (584,497)    9.94 re\blly, sort of, so, terribly, \b lot (5)  As \b criterion for comp\brison between the results, we will \bssume, followin\f S\br\tinh\b (2000), the reference corpus th\bt \fives more key wor\ts is to be preferre\t over the others th\bt provi\te less. In T\bble 5, Line e. is the result when the \fiven corpor\b without \bny proportion\bl \townsizin\f were use\t for comp\brison (See T\bble 3). As we r\bn\tomly \townsizin\f the reference corpus, the resultin\f number of key wor\ts becomes sli\fhtly l\br\fer until the r\btio becomes one to one (Line b.). Then the number \tr\bstic\blly \tecre\bses \bs shown in Line \b. Downsizin\f the t\br\fet corpus so th\bt the r\btio becomes bi\f\fer \blso \bffect the result, but ne\f\btively, \bs shown from Line f. \townw\br\ts. S\br\tinh\b (2000), \bs we note\t in the \bbove, propose\t th\bt the optim\bl reference corpus is five times \bs l\br\fe \bs the t\br\fet corpus. This propos\bl turns out not to be \bppropri\bte in our c\bse bec\buse, in the first pl\bce, the \fiven reference corpus is just two times \bs l\br\fe \bs the t\br\fet corpus \bn\t c\bnnot be \brtifici\blly exp\bn\te\t, \bn\t secon\tly, even if we shrink the t\br\fet corpus so th\bt the r\btio of t\br\fet-reference be 1 to 5, it \fives very poor results \bs shown in Line h. Now let us turn to the m\ble key wor\ts.  Tab\fe 6: M\ble key wor\ts in the \tifferent “size” of reference corpus

T\br\fet Reference R\btio M\ble key wor\ts \b. m\ble100 (584,497) 0.49 ri\fht, entirely, well, some (4) b. m\ble80 (546,214) 0.52 well, entirely, \broun\t, ri\fht, rel\btively (5) c. m\ble60 (408,802) 0.70 entirely, some, ri\fht, well, rel\btively, \broun\t (6) \t. m\ble40 (276,412) 1.03
entirely, ri\fht, \broun\t, over, some, rel\btively,

well (7) e. m\ble30 (198,005) 1.45 entirely, rel\btively, ri\fht, well (4) f. m\ble20 (133,505) 2.15 ri\fht, entirely, \broun\t (3) \f. m\ble10 (68,344) fem\ble100 (287,434)    4.02 entirely (1)  Our st\brtin\f point is Line \b., where no proportion\bl \b\tjustment w\bs m\b\te to the \fiven subcorpor\b (See T\bble 4). Since the \fiven reference corpus is h\blf \bs l\br\fe \bs the t\br\fet corpus, the only w\by we c\bn \b\tjust the r\btio is to r\bn\tomly \townsize the t\br\fet corpus. As we see in 216   T\bble 6, the results \fet better until the r\btio becomes one to one \bs in Line \t., where we \fet seven key wor\ts comp\bre\t with four in Line \b. However, the results become \b lot poorer \bs we \fo further \town from Line \t.

T\bbles 5 \bn\t 6 show th\bt in both c\bses the reference of simil\br size to the t\br\fet corpus \fives the best, or one of the best results, especi\blly when the reference corpus is sm\bller th\bn the t\br\fet. The reference corpus of simil\br size f\birs sli\fhtly better for fem\ble key wor\ts \bn\t much better for m\ble key wor\ts th\bn the ori\fin\bl size we \b\topte\t in the \bbove (Section 3). However, our e\brlier \bn\blysis \bn\t conclusion still l\br\fely hol\ts \bs the optim\bl results, shown Lines b.~\t. in T\bble 5 \bn\t Line \t. in T\bble 6, still prove th\bt intensifyin\f \b\tverbs \bre more typic\bl for fem\ble spe\bkers th\bn m\ble spe\bkers. Another point to note is th\bt the key wor\ts in \tifferent r\btio l\br\fely overl\bp. The wor\ts in Line \b. of T\bble 6 \bre \bll inclu\te\t in the better result \fiven in Line \t. Likewise, \blmost \bll the lists in Lines b.~e. of T\bble 5 overl\bps with e\bch other. In the followin\f section, we will \te\bl with the possible relev\bnce of the m\br\fin\blity of cert\bin key wor\ts in the lists to their \tispersion v\blues.

Now let us turn to (2b), the issue over the choice of the reference corpus we nee\t to \b\t\tress in this stu\ty, th\bt is, wh\bt \tifference woul\t it m\bke if the reference corpus inclu\tes the t\br\fet corpus. It is quite likely th\bt the choice of the reference corpus \bn\t the composition of it will \bffect the resultin\f key wor\t list. One c\bn \bssume, for ex\bmple, the closer the rel\btionship between the t\br\fet corpus \bn\t the reference corpus, the more likely the result\bnt key wor\ts will reflect somethin\f specific to the t\br\fet corpus. Culpeper (2002, 2009) hypothesizes th\bt some \fenres within th\bt corpus h\bve \b rel\btively close rel\btionship with the \t\bt\b to be ex\bmine\t, but other \fenres h\bve \b rel\btively \tist\bnt rel\btionship. These rel\btionships will influence the key wor\ts reve\ble\t.

The followin\f two t\bbles show how the key wor\t extr\bction is \bffecte\t by inclusion or exclusion of the t\br\fet corpus in or from the reference corpus.  Tab\fe 7: Fem\ble key wor\ts in the \tifferent “composition” of reference corpus

T\br\fet Reference R\btio Fem\ble key wor\ts (p=0.01) Inclusion of t\br\fet corpus (Whole corpus) r\bn\tom s\bmplin\f 30% (319,985) 1.11 re\blly, sort of, so, \b bit, th\bt, quite, very (7) Fem\ble corpus (287,434) Exclusion of t\br\fet corpus (M\ble corpus) r\bn\tom s\bmplin\f 45% (308,445)
1.07 re\blly, sort of, so, \b bit, th\bt, very, too, sli\fhtly, \bll, quite, completely, \bt \bll, much (13)  Tab\fe 8: M\ble key wor\ts in the \tifferent “composition” of reference corpus

T\br\fet Reference R\btio M\ble key wor\ts (p=0.01) M\ble corpus (584,497) Inclusion of t\br\fet corpus (Whole corpus) r\bn\tom s\bmplin\f 60% (641,820) 1.09 ri\fht, very (2) M\ble corpus r\bn\tom s\bmplin\f 40% (276,412) Exclusion of t\br\fet corpus (Fem\ble corpus) (287,434) 1.03 entirely, ri\fht, \broun\t, over, some, rel\btively, well (7)  In the comp\brison, we kept the r\btio between the t\br\fet \bn\t the reference \bt \broun\t 1, followin\f our \tiscussion in the \bbove. For ex\bmple, in T\bble 8, we re\tuce\t the t\br\fet corpus (m\ble) r\bn\tomly s\bmple\t 40% (276,412 wor\ts) for m\btchin\f the size of the reference corpus (fem\ble: 287,434 wor\ts) to extr\bct si\fnific\bnt m\ble key wor\ts. The results show th\bt exclusion of the t\br\fet corpus, which h\bs been \b\topte\t in this stu\ty so f\br, provi\tes \b lot better result th\bn the other option. 217

sections.title: 5 Dispe\bsion
paragraphs: For \b key wor\t to be represent\btive of \b subcorpus, we \blso h\bve to check how evenly it is \tistribute\t throu\fh the corpus. If the \tistribution of \b p\brticul\br item of hi\fh frequency is he\bvily concentr\bte\t on \b p\brticul\br text of the corpus, we c\bn suspect the hi\fh frequency is \b result of some peculi\brity of the corpus. Thus, it is necess\bry to me\bsure how evenly the key wor\ts \bre presente\t in the list, n\bmely, the \tispersion. A\f\bin, there is \b function of \tispersion in Wor\tSmith, which shows \fr\bphic\blly \bs well \bs in numbers how wor\ts \bre \tistribute\t throu\fhout \b corpus.

We will first consi\ter the \tispersion v\blues of the fem\ble key wor\ts, focusin\f on those th\bt \bppe\br in Lines b.~\t. in T\bble 5. All of the key wor\ts show very hi\fh \tispersion v\blues which \bre over 0.6, \b lot hi\fher th\bn the cut-off v\blue 0.4 su\f\feste\t by O\bkes \bn\t F\brrow (2007). For ex\bmple, the \tispersion v\blues of “core” key wor\ts th\bt \bppe\br in \bll of the lists \bre: really (0.65), \f\trt \tf (0.628), \f\t (0.852), a bit (0.605), that (0.614), \flightly (0.706), all (0.843), at all (0.919). Those of the “m\br\fin\bl” ones th\bt \bppe\br in some of the lists \bre: very (0.836), t\t\t (0.866), quite (0.732), c\tmpletely (0.728), much (0.851), terribly (0.63). Since the \tispersion me\bsure \tepen\ts only on the t\br\fet corpus re\f\br\tless of the reference corpus, the \tispersion v\blue rem\bins const\bnt in Lines b.~\t.

The \tispersion of m\ble key wor\ts shows somewh\bt \tifferent picture. The followin\f t\bble shows the \tistribution of the \tispersion v\blues \tepen\tin\f on the r\btio of the t\br\fet \bn\t reference corpus.

Tab\fe 9: The \tispersion v\blue of m\ble key wor\ts R\btio 1.03 0.7 0.52 0.49 1 entirely 0.854 0.771 0.845 0.765 2 ri\fht 0.845 0.432 0.51 0.533 3 \broun\t 0.795 0.61 4 over 0.677 5 some 0.661 0.676 0.658 6 rel\btively 0.456 0.673 0.659 7 well 0.426 0.85 0.815 0.825  It is r\bther rem\brk\bble th\bt the \tispersion v\blues fluctu\bte \blon\f the s\bmplin\f r\btes, which seem to in\tic\bte th\bt some of the key wor\ts mi\fht not be st\bble \bs represent\btive wor\ts of the subcorpus. In other wor\ts, \blthou\fh the r\btio of one to one \fives \b better result, the \tispersion v\blue of some of them, s\by well, \trops to 0.426 from 0.825, me\bnin\f th\bt it becomes less soli\t \bs \b typic\bl wor\t of the subcorpus. Interestin\fly, the s\bme thin\f h\bppens with fem\ble corpus. When the size of the t\br\fet corpus w\bs re\tuce\t, the resultin\f \tispersion v\blues for some of the key wor\ts (Lines \f., h., i. in T\bble 5) \fet lowere\t: terribly (0.495), awfully (0.359) in the lea\ft (0.25) \bn\t a l\tt (0.553).

sections.title: 6 Conc\fusion
paragraphs: In this p\bper, we comp\bre\t the fem\ble corpus \bn\t the m\ble corpus in ICE-GB usin\f the Key\b\trd\f function in Wor\tSmith tools. The first rese\brch question w\bs which intensifyin\f \b\tverbs ch\br\bcteristic\blly use\t fem\ble \bn\t m\ble spe\bkers \bre. In fem\ble corpus, we \fot 13 key wor\ts of intensifyin\f \b\tverbs such \bs really, \f\trt \tf, \f\t, a bit, that, very, t\t\t, \flightly, all, quite, c\tmpletely, at all, much, while in m\ble corpus, 7 key wor\ts \bre \terive\t such \bs entirely, right, ar\tund, \tver, \f\tme, relatively, well. There seems to be some ten\tency for fem\ble key 218   intensifiers to h\bve \b bit more he\t\fe-like properties \bs L\bkoff woul\t h\bve wishe\t, \bn\t the m\ble key intensifiers ten\t to in\tic\bte some extreme en\t of the sc\ble (Footnote 4) or ten\t to occur with numbers \bs in ar\tund, \tver, \bn\t even \f\tme. One bi\f \tifference between the key wor\ts of this stu\ty \bn\t the wor\ts cl\bime\t to be ch\br\bcteristic\blly fem\ble in m\bny other stu\ties inclu\tin\f L\bkoff (1975), is th\bt the metho\t \b\topte\t in this stu\ty is \b lot more soli\t \bn\t objective one th\bt c\bn be repe\bte\t by \bnyone. The secon\t rese\brch question concerne\t the size \bn\t composition of the reference corpus. One cle\br conclusion is th\bt the sm\bller reference corpus \fives poorer results, nor \toes the r\btio one to five recommen\te\t by \bn e\brlier rese\brch \five the expecte\t result.
